  • The Blue Man Group in NYC

     Jan 28, 2017

    I traveled up to New York this morning for a weekend in Manhattan.

    Kristina and I walked through Times Square/Central Park and ended the day by seeing the Blue Man Group at Astor Theatre. Here are a couple pics.

  • Museum view in React

     Jan 27, 2017

    My web work day got shortened because I went to work as a photographer tonight in DC.

    One of the things I was learning about before I left was how to create a museum view for Stash's cards. The main problem with the current version is that items are added in columns instead of in rows. The only way to get the items to position themselves in rows is to use a technique called Masonry.

    There are plugins that enable this dynamic positioning in React that I will need to use to create this effect. That'll have to wait a couple days though because I'm headed to NYC with Kristina tomorrow morning 🗽!

  • Embodying the product manager mindset

     Jan 26, 2017

    I continue to read Cracking the PM Interview and many of the PMs interviewed in the book emphasize the importance of being constantly curious. I agree with this ideology and will push myself to learn something new everyday.

    Today, I came across designkit.org. It's a fantastic resource for learning about human-centered design, crafted by IDEO.

    This is an intro video they created about human-centered design.

    IDEO has also created some really insightful design methods that are worth checking out.

  • Committed to uncovering the truth

     Jan 25, 2017

    The truth is out there, but recently people with power have been using their influence to publicly dispute facts and create obstacles to make it difficult for citizens to access important information.

    Osebo and I decided that we needed to do our part in helping people access fact based information on environmental, social, economic, and educational issues.

    We chose the name "Hidden Info" because we're committed to uncovering the truth. We'll strive to be unbiased and our writing will require a great deal of research and fact checking to ensure we put out is 100% truthful. We will be providing sources for our findings.

    Today we whipped up a basic prototype just to get a sense for what we need to include in the experience.

  • California job apps and Stashing with Diego

     Jan 24, 2017

    I applied to two PM jobs in San Jose that look promising. I've always loved the valley and if I do land a job out there, it would be almost impossible to decline.

    After work hours, I attended a hacker meetup with Diego.

    We spent time working on the error messages for user registration.

    Osebo also wanted to see what it would look like if we used a museum style view for Stash's cards, so I built a quick prototype.

    The design is nice, but items that only have a favicon or no image at all create gaps in the layout. Another concern is that it only adds content to the left column rather than adding items across horizontally in rows. That may cause confusion for the user in regards to which items were most recently saved.

    I don't think we're quite ready to implement something like the museum view until we can grab screenshots of webpages that don't have meta images. More on this in the future.

  • Left/Right arrows and powerful climate change imagery

     Jan 23, 2017

    After refactoring and rewriting quite a few things, Diego and I got the left and right arrows working for Stash.

    Stash Left/Right Arrows Demo

    Things are coming along and we will be pushing an update in the near future.

    I also did some research on climate change today and found a great climate change website that has accumulated some compelling imagery. The creators conducted research about each image's effectiveness is conveying global warming.

    Here are some examples:

    Air Pollution China

    Nigerian Oil Fire

    Child and E-Waste

    These images are disturbing and more people should see them. Find the rest of the pics and the research behind them here.

  • Reorganizing my activity sheet

     Jan 22, 2017

    I want to make it easier for people to view my activity sheet without having to click through titles to see each post.

    So I'm using Jekyll's excerpt mechanism to show each post on the home page. I also restyled the way the posts are presented on the homepage to provide clear separation between each entry.

    I only got a few hours of sleep last night because I had to be up early for a wedding showcase this morning.

    I was in heavy sales mode with our Mirror Booth and helped my photography company get over 100 client sign ups.

  • Photos from the Washingtonian Inaugural Party

     Jan 21, 2017

    Tonight, I was a photographer at the 2017 Washingtonian Inaugural Party.

    It was a busy night and my friend David was able to capture a quick timelapse while I was shooting.

    A cool bonus was getting to try out a 360 degree camera station with Mandi.

  • An alarming transition

     Jan 20, 2017

    Donald Trump became president today.

    I don't want get too deep into politics, but there is one thing that happened today that is particularly concerning to me.

    Our nation is one of the largest contributors to the earth's changing climate and the science is being buried by this new administration.

    How can we make progress towards solving this global problem if this country's leaders deny the issue exists?

    The data needs to be distributed to the masses and I'm more motivated than ever to create this interactive infographic about climate change with Osebo. I'm holding myself to it.

  • React, Redux and progress with Stash

     Jan 19, 2017

    Today, Diego and I spent some quality time together working on Stash. We're working on creating left and right arrows for moving between items within the overlay.

    It required quite of bit of refactoring and requires manipulating the global state with Redux.

    I'm happy that Diego has been taking the time to walk me through the relationships between the actions, dispatches, reducers and states.

    Learning this component based framework is hard work, but I know it will pay off. Excited to share the experience with you soon.
